Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Expectation2: Communicate and offer small mutual help like receiving packages or checking in during emergencies
Situation2: The neighbor is traveling for a week and asked about deliveries as a planned power interruption is expected in the building.
Story: This weekend, my younger sister is graduating from college, and my whole family is gathering to celebrate her achievement. She’s been working so hard, and I promised I’d be there early to help set up and make her day special. At the same time, my neighbor, Mrs. Lee, is leaving for a week-long trip and asked if I could keep an eye on her apartment, especially since there’s a planned power outage in the building. She’s expecting a couple of important packages, and she’s always been there for me—watering my plants, checking my mail when I’m away. I want to support my sister and be the reliable brother she counts on, but I also don’t want to let down Mrs. Lee, who trusts me as a good neighbor. The thought of disappointing either of them makes my stomach twist. I keep replaying their requests in my mind, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure how I can possibly meet everyone’s expectations at once.
